skill.name: pubmed-database
skill.description: Direct REST API access to PubMed. Advanced Boolean/MeSH queries, E-utilities API, batch processing, citation management. For Python workflows, prefer biopython (Bio.Entrez). Use this for direct HTTP/REST work or custom API implementations.
skill.summary: Direct REST API access to PubMed for biomedical literature searches
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. This is a documentation-only skill providing reference materials for PubMed queries. The detected patterns (backticks, API key placeholders, URLs) are markdown documentation elements, not executable code. The skill contains no executable code, no network calls, and no credential access.

content.value_statement: Researchers need efficient access to biomedical literature for systematic reviews and evidence-based research. This skill provides comprehensive documentation for PubMed queries including Boolean operators, MeSH terms, and E-utilities API access.
actual_capabilities: Construct advanced Boolean search queries with field tags and operators
Use Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) for precise biomedical searching
Access PubMed programmatically via E-utilities REST API
Build systematic review search strategies using PICO framework
Find related articles and citation networks via ELink
Export search results in multiple formats for reference management
limitations: Provides documentation only; requires separate HTTP tool for API calls
No full-text access; citations and abstracts only
Rate limits apply (3 requests/second without API key)

use_cases.title: Systematic Literature Review
use_cases.description: Construct comprehensive search strategies using Boolean operators, MeSH terms, and filters to find all relevant studies for systematic reviews and meta-analyses.

use_cases.title: Biomedical Research Queries
use_cases.description: Search for articles on specific diseases, treatments, or drug interactions using precise field tags and controlled vocabulary.

use_cases.title: Programmatic Data Extraction
use_cases.description: Build automated workflows to search PubMed and extract article metadata using the E-utilities API for large-scale research projects.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Article Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find recent articles on {topic} published in 2024. Use appropriate MeSH terms and field tags to limit results to English language research papers.
prompt_templates.scenario: Simple literature search with time and language constraints

prompt_templates.title: Clinical Trial Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for randomized controlled trials comparing {treatment_a} versus {treatment_b} for {condition} from 2020 to 2024. Include only free full-text articles.
prompt_templates.scenario: Finding clinical evidence with publication type and text availability filters

prompt_templates.title: Systematic Review Query
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the PICO framework to construct a comprehensive search strategy for {clinical_question}. Include all relevant synonyms and MeSH terms.
prompt_templates.scenario: Building systematic review search with population, intervention, comparison, outcome structure

prompt_templates.title: API-Based Batch Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Python script using the E-utilities API to search for articles matching {criteria}, retrieve up to 500 PMIDs using the history server, and export results to a CSV file with PMID, title, and abstract.
prompt_templates.scenario: Programmatic PubMed access with batch processing and data export

output_examples.input: Search for systematic reviews on machine learning in medical imaging published 2023-2024
output: Query: (machine learning[mh] OR deep learning[tiab] OR artificial intelligence[tiab]) AND (medical imaging[mh] OR radiology[tiab] OR diagnostic imaging[tiab]) AND systematic review[pt] AND 2023:2024[dp]
- Deep learning in radiology: a systematic review (PMID: 38012345)
- Machine learning for medical image analysis: systematic review (PMID: 37987654)

output_examples.input: Find clinical trials on metformin for type 2 diabetes with cardiovascular outcomes
output: Query: (metformin[nm] OR biguanides[mh]) AND diabetes mellitus, type 2[mh] AND cardiovascular diseases[mh] AND randomized controlled trial[pt] AND hasabstract[text]
- Metformin and cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes (PMID: 36543210)

best_practices: Start with broad searches using MeSH terms, then narrow with field tags and filters for precision
Include synonyms and alternative terms to capture all relevant literature
Use the history server (usehistory=y) for large result sets exceeding 500 articles
Obtain an API key from NCBI for higher rate limits (10 requests/second vs 3)
anti_patterns: Using only free-text terms without MeSH terms misses indexed articles
Running many small API requests instead of batch operations wastes rate limits
Not caching results leads to redundant API calls and slower workflows
Ignoring automatic term mapping can produce unexpected search results

faq.question: What is the difference between MeSH terms and text word searches?
faq.answer: MeSH terms search the controlled vocabulary index where all articles are manually tagged. Text word searches only match terms appearing in titles and abstracts. Combining both provides comprehensive coverage.

faq.question: How do I get an API key for PubMed E-utilities?
faq.answer: Register for a free NCBI account at ncbi.nlm.nih.gov, then visit your account settings to generate an API key. Include it in requests with the api_key parameter for higher rate limits.

faq.question: What are the PubMed rate limits?
faq.answer: Without an API key: 3 requests per second. With an API key: 10 requests per second. Always include a descriptive User-Agent header in your requests.

faq.question: How do I handle large result sets with thousands of articles?
faq.answer: Use the history server: first call ESearch with usehistory=y to store results, then use the WebEnv and QueryKey parameters with ESummary or EFetch to retrieve data in batches of up to 500 records per request.

faq.question: What export formats are available for PubMed results?
faq.answer: Common formats include MEDLINE (text), XML (structured data), RIS (reference managers), and NBIB (EndNote). Use the rettype and retmode parameters to specify your desired format.

faq.question: How do I find articles that cite a specific paper?
faq.answer: Use the ELink utility with dbfrom=pubmed, db=pubmed, and cmd=cite. This returns PMIDs of articles that cite the input article. Note that citation data may not be complete for very recent publications.
